article.headline: Page gets Pitt on track in new building
article.linkText: Pittsburgh quick to adapt, turns back Duquesne
article.story:
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- The unaccustomed top-five national ranking took
some time to get adjusted to, so did the new building and a crowd
twice the size Pittsburgh normally plays before at home.

	   Once Pitt got the opening-night jitters out of the way, the No.
4 Panthers (No. 5 AP) overcame a below-average game from star Brandin Knight
to pull away for an 82-67 victory over stubborn city rival Duquesne
on Saturday night.

	   The first men's game in the $96.4 million Petersen Events Center
_ easily the fanciest and most expensive ever built on a Big East
Conference campus -- was unexpectedly tight for much of the game in
a rivalry that has been anything but close.

	   "I think we were overly excited," said Julius Page, who led
Pitt with 17 points. "We were real nervous about the game, and
everybody was really pumped up. We were trying to live up to our
ranking. We've been hyped up for so long, and we wanted to prove it
(the ranking) so fast."

	   Now that the Panthers have played a game in their new arena,
coach Ben Howland said, "It's home now and we can settle down and
move forward."

	   It is a contrast to a year ago, when the Panthers were picked to
finish next-to-last in their Big East division and didn't break
into the national rankings until winning 15 of their first 16. They
went on to finish 29-6, a school record for victories.

	   The Panthers (1-0), ranked in the Top 5 at the start of a season
for the first time in 15 years, trailed until the final minute of
the first half before scoring the final five points of the half.
They kept that momentum by starting the second half with a 16-7 run
led by Page's eight points and opened a 49-36 lead.

	   Duquesne (0-1), which has beaten Pitt only three times in 24
meetings over the last 20 years, stubbornly hung around for most of
the second half, trailing by five points with 8 minutes to play.
Pitt finally pulled away with an 11-0 run over a 5-minute span that
lasted until just over a minute to play.

	   "For us to win, the stars had to line up, the moon had to line
up, everything had to be perfect," Duquesne coach Danny Nee said.
"We responded well at times ... but they took it up to another
level in the second half and got the game under control."

	   Pittsburgh finally wore down the rebuilding Dukes with its size,
depth and a balanced offense. Neither team shot particularly well,
with Pitt shooting 43.3 percent and Duquesne 40.6 percent.

	   "It was tough to play this first game, with it being the
historic first game here," said Howland, last season's national
coach of the year. "There was a lot of anxiousness on our part,
but we finally settled down in the second half."

	   Pitt held a 51-35 rebounding edge, with guard Carl Krauser
coming off the bench to score 11 points and get a game-high nine
rebounds in his first game for the Panthers.

	   Knight, a third-team All-American last season while leading Pitt
to the third round of the NCAA tournament, scored 13 points but did not shoot well -- he was 6-of-14 overall and 0-for-2 from the line -- or play his usually strong floor game. He also was 1-of-5 on 3-pointers.

	   "There are a lot of expectations on these guys," Howland said.
"Brandin Knight and Julius Page are stars in this town now. That's
a lot to put on a 20-year-old. But they're handling it great."

	   Duquesne, which has not beaten a Top 10 team on the road in 40
years, got 13 points each from Jimmy Tricco, a transfer playing for
the first time since the 2001 NCAA tournament with Gonzaga, and
reserve guard Brad Midgley.

	   The 12,508-seat Petersen Events Center, which is sold out for
the season, replaces the 6,798-seat Fitzgerald Field House, the
Panthers' home court for 50 years.
